poem.verse: 1The Song of Songs, which is Solomon’s.
2Oh, that he would kiss me with the kisses of his mouth!

poetryblock.poem: For your caresses are more delightful than wine.

poem.verse: 3The fragrance of your perfume is intoxicating;

poetryblock.poem: your name is perfume poured out.
No wonder young women adore you.
Oh, that the king would bring me to his chambers.
We will rejoice and be glad in you;
we will celebrate your caresses more than wine.
It is only right that they adore you.
I am dark like the tents of Kedar,
yet lovely like the curtains of Solomon.

poem.verse: 6Do not stare at me because I am dark,

poetryblock.poem: for the sun has gazed on me.
My mother’s sons were angry with me;
they made me take care of the vineyards.
I have not taken care of my own vineyard.
Where do you pasture your sheep?
Where do you let them rest at noon?
Why should I be like one who veils herself
beside the flocks of your companions?
most beautiful of women,
follow the tracks of the flock,
and pasture your young goats
near the shepherds’ tents.
to a mare among Pharaoh’s chariots.
your neck with its necklace.

poem.verse: 11We will make gold jewellery for you,

poetryblock.poem: accented with silver.

poem.verse: 12While the king is on his couch,

poetryblock.poem: my perfume releases its fragrance.

poem.verse: 13The one I love is a sachet of myrrh to me,

poetryblock.poem: spending the night between my breasts.

poem.verse: 14The one I love is a cluster of henna blossoms to me,

poetryblock.poem: in the vineyards of En-gedi.
How very beautiful!
Your eyes are doves.
How delightful!
Our bed is verdant;

poem.verse: 17the beams of our house are cedars,

poetryblock.poem: and our rafters are cypresses.
a lily of the valleys.
so is my darling among the young women.

poem.verse: 3Like an apricot tree among the trees of the forest,

poetryblock.poem: so is my love among the young men.
I delight to sit in his shade,
and his fruit is sweet to my taste.

poem.verse: 4He brought me to the banquet hall,

poetryblock.poem: and he looked on me with love.
refresh me with apricots,
for I am lovesick.

poem.verse: 6May his left hand be under my head,

poetryblock.poem: and his right arm embrace me.

poem.verse: 7Young women of Jerusalem, I charge you

poetryblock.poem: by the gazelles and the wild does of the field,
do not stir up or awaken love
until the appropriate time.
Look! Here he comes,
leaping over the mountains,
bounding over the hills.
or a young stag.
See, he is standing behind our wall,
gazing through the windows,
peering through the lattice.
Arise, my darling.
Come away, my beautiful one.
the rain has ended and gone away.
The time of singing has come,
and the turtledove’s cooing is heard in our land.
the blossoming vines give off their fragrance.
Arise, my darling.
Come away, my beautiful one.

poem.verse: 14My dove, in the clefts of the rock,

poetryblock.poem: in the crevices of the cliff,
let me see your face,
let me hear your voice;
for your voice is sweet,
and your face is lovely.
the little foxes that ruin the vineyards –
for our vineyards are in bloom.

poem.verse: 16My love is mine and I am his;

poetryblock.poem: he feeds among the lilies.
and the shadows flee,
turn around, my love, and be like a gazelle
or a young stag on the divided mountains.
I sought the one I love;
I sought him, but did not find him.

poem.verse: 2I will arise now and go about the city,

poetryblock.poem: through the streets and the squares.
I will seek the one I love.
I sought him, but did not find him.

poem.verse: 3The guards who go about the city found me.

poetryblock.poem: I asked them, ‘Have you seen the one I love? ’
when I found the one I love.
I held on to him and would not let him go
until I brought him to my mother’s house –
to the chamber of the one who conceived me.

poem.verse: 5Young women of Jerusalem, I charge you

poetryblock.poem: by the gazelles and the wild does of the field,
do not stir up or awaken love
until the appropriate time.

poem.verse: 6Who is this coming up from the wilderness

poetryblock.poem: like columns of smoke,
scented with myrrh and frankincense
from every fragrant powder of the merchant?
surrounded by sixty warriors
from the mighty men of Israel.

poem.verse: 8All of them are skilled with swords

poetryblock.poem: and trained in warfare.
Each has his sword at his side
to guard against the terror of the night.

poem.verse: 9King Solomon made a carriage for himself

poetryblock.poem: with wood from Lebanon.
its back of gold,
and its seat of purple.
Its interior is inlaid with love
by the young women of Jerusalem.
and gaze at King Solomon,
wearing the crown his mother placed on him
on the day of his wedding –
the day of his heart’s rejoicing.
How very beautiful!
Behind your veil,
your eyes are doves.
Your hair is like a flock of goats
streaming down Mount Gilead.

poem.verse: 2Your teeth are like a flock of newly shorn sheep

poetryblock.poem: coming up from washing,
each one bearing twins,
and none has lost its young.

poem.verse: 3Your lips are like a scarlet cord,

poetryblock.poem: and your mouth is lovely.
Behind your veil,
your brow is like a slice of pomegranate.

poem.verse: 4Your neck is like the tower of David,

poetryblock.poem: constructed in layers.
A thousand shields are hung on it –
all of them shields of warriors.
twins of a gazelle, that feed among the lilies.
and the shadows flee,
I will make my way to the mountain of myrrh
and the hill of frankincense.
there is no imperfection in you.

poem.verse: 8Come with me from Lebanon, my bride;

poetryblock.poem: come with me from Lebanon!
Descend from the peak of Amana,
from the summit of Senir and Hermon,
from the dens of the lions,
from the mountains of the leopards.

poem.verse: 9You have captured my heart, my sister, my bride.

poetryblock.poem: You have captured my heart with one glance of your eyes,
with one jewel of your necklace.

poem.verse: 10How delightful your caresses are, my sister, my bride.

poetryblock.poem: Your caresses are much better than wine,
and the fragrance of your perfume than any balsam.

poem.verse: 11Your lips drip sweetness like the honeycomb, my bride.

poetryblock.poem: Honey and milk are under your tongue.
The fragrance of your garments is like the fragrance of Lebanon.

poem.verse: 12My sister, my bride, you are a locked garden –

poetryblock.poem: a locked garden and a sealed spring.

poem.verse: 13Your branches are a paradise of pomegranates

poetryblock.poem: with choicest fruits;
henna with nard,
with all the trees of frankincense,
myrrh and aloes,
with all the best spices.
a well of flowing water
streaming from Lebanon.
come, south wind.
Blow on my garden,
and spread the fragrance of its spices.
Let my love come to his garden
and eat its choicest fruits.

poem.verse: 1I have come to my garden ​– ​my sister, my bride.

poetryblock.poem: I gather my myrrh with my spices.
I eat my honeycomb with my honey.
I drink my wine with my milk.
Eat, friends!
Drink, be intoxicated with caresses!

poem.verse: 2I was sleeping, but my heart was awake.

poetryblock.poem: A sound! My love was knocking!
Open to me, my sister, my darling,
my dove, my perfect one.
For my head is drenched with dew,
my hair with droplets of the night.
How can I put it back on?
I have washed my feet.
How can I get them dirty?

poem.verse: 4My love thrust his hand through the opening,

poetryblock.poem: and my feelings were stirred for him.

poem.verse: 5I rose to open for my love.

poetryblock.poem: My hands dripped with myrrh,
my fingers with flowing myrrh
on the handles of the bolt.
but my love had turned and gone away.
My heart sank because he had left.
I sought him, but did not find him.
I called him, but he did not answer.

poem.verse: 7The guards who go about the city found me.

poetryblock.poem: They beat and wounded me;
they took my cloak from me –
the guardians of the walls.

poem.verse: 8Young women of Jerusalem, I charge you,

poetryblock.poem: if you find my love,
tell him that I am lovesick.

poem.verse: 9What makes the one you love better than another,

poetryblock.poem: most beautiful of women?
What makes him better than another,
that you would give us this charge?
notable among ten thousand.
His hair is wavy
and black as a raven.
beside flowing streams,
washed in milk
and set like jewels.

poem.verse: 13His cheeks are like beds of spice,

poetryblock.poem: mounds of perfume.
His lips are lilies,
dripping with flowing myrrh.
set with beryl.
His body is an ivory panel
covered with lapis lazuli.
set on pedestals of pure gold.
His presence is like Lebanon,
as majestic as the cedars.
He is absolutely desirable.
This is my love, and this is my friend,
young women of Jerusalem.
most beautiful of women?
Which way has he turned?
We will seek him with you.

poem.verse: 2My love has gone down to his garden,

poetryblock.poem: to beds of spice,
to feed in the gardens
and gather lilies.

poem.verse: 3I am my love’s and my love is mine;

poetryblock.poem: he feeds among the lilies.

poem.verse: 4You are as beautiful as Tirzah, my darling,

poetryblock.poem: lovely as Jerusalem,
awe-inspiring as an army with banners.
for they captivate me.
Your hair is like a flock of goats
streaming down from Gilead.

poem.verse: 6Your teeth are like a flock of ewes

poetryblock.poem: coming up from washing,
each one having a twin,
and not one missing.
your brow is like a slice of pomegranate.
and eighty concubines
and young women without number.

poem.verse: 9But my dove, my virtuous one, is unique;

poetryblock.poem: she is the favourite of her mother,
perfect to the one who gave her birth.
Women see her and declare her fortunate;
queens and concubines also, and they sing her praises:

poem.verse: 10Who is this who shines like the dawn,

poetryblock.poem: as beautiful as the moon,
bright as the sun,
awe-inspiring as an army with banners?

poem.verse: 11I came down to the walnut grove

poetryblock.poem: to see the blossoms of the valley,
to see if the vines were budding
and the pomegranates blooming.

poem.verse: 12I didn’t know what was happening to me.

poetryblock.poem: I felt like I was
in a chariot with a nobleman.
Come back, come back, that we may look at you!
How you gaze at the Shulammite,
as you look at the dance of the two camps!

poem.verse: 1How beautiful are your sandalled feet, princess!

poetryblock.poem: The curves of your thighs are like jewellery,
the handiwork of a master.
it never lacks mixed wine.
Your belly is a mound of wheat
surrounded by lilies.
twins of a gazelle.

poem.verse: 4Your neck is like a tower of ivory,

poetryblock.poem: your eyes like pools in Heshbon
by Bath-rabbim’s gate.
Your nose is like the tower of Lebanon
looking towards Damascus.

poem.verse: 5Your head crowns you like Mount Carmel,

poetryblock.poem: the hair of your head like purple cloth –
a king could be held captive in your tresses.

poem.verse: 6How beautiful you are and how pleasant,

poetryblock.poem: my love, with such delights!

poem.verse: 7Your stature is like a palm tree;

poetryblock.poem: your breasts are clusters of fruit.

poem.verse: 8I said, ‘I will climb the palm tree

poetryblock.poem: and take hold of its fruit.’
May your breasts be like clusters of grapes,
and the fragrance of your breath like apricots.
flowing smoothly for my love,
gliding past my lips and teeth!
and his desire is for me.
let’s go to the field;
let’s spend the night among the henna blossoms.
let’s see if the vine has budded,
if the blossom has opened,
if the pomegranates are in bloom.
There I will give you my caresses.
and at our doors is every delicacy,
both new and old.
I have treasured them up for you, my love.

poem.verse: 1If only I could treat you like my brother,

poetryblock.poem: one who nursed at my mother’s breasts,
I would find you in public and kiss you,
and no one would scorn me.

poem.verse: 2I would lead you, I would take you,

poetryblock.poem: to the house of my mother who taught me.
I would give you spiced wine to drink
from the juice of my pomegranate.

poem.verse: 3May his left hand be under my head,

poetryblock.poem: and his right arm embrace me.

poem.verse: 4Young women of Jerusalem, I charge you,

poetryblock.poem: do not stir up or awaken love
until the appropriate time.

poem.verse: 5Who is this coming up from the wilderness,

poetryblock.poem: leaning on the one she loves?
I awakened you under the apricot tree.
There your mother conceived you;
there she conceived and gave you birth.

poem.verse: 6Set me as a seal on your heart,

poetryblock.poem: as a seal on your arm.
For love is as strong as death;
jealousy is as unrelenting as Sheol.
Love’s flames are fiery flames –
an almighty flame!
rivers cannot sweep it away.
If a man were to give all his wealth for love,
it would be utterly scorned.
she has no breasts.
What will we do for our sister
on the day she is spoken for?
we will build a silver barricade on her.
If she is a door,
we will enclose her with cedar planks.
and my breasts like towers.
So to him I have become
like one who finds peace.
He leased the vineyard to tenants.
Each was to bring for his fruit
one thousand pieces of silver.
The one thousand are for you, Solomon,
but two hundred for those who take care of its fruits.
companions are listening for your voice;
let me hear you!
and be like a gazelle
or a young stag
on the mountains of spices.
